Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Cloning and Characterization of OPENED IMMATURE FLOWER

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Many studies of gene expression have focused on transcription levels, leaving alternative splicing, a conserved mechanism that increases transcript diversity, relatively unexplored. This project seeks to deepen understanding of alternative splicing by identifying new factors within the splicing network of plants. In Arabidopsis thaliana, SR45 belongs to a family of factors that play important roles in splicing events. The gene OPENED IMMATURE FLOWER (OIF) was recently identified as a genetic enhancer of SR45. To understand how OIF modulates the splicing regulatory function of SR45, the OIF gene will be isolated by map-based cloning and functional complementation by transformation of candidate OIF genes into plants that are mutant for SR45 and OIF. New factors in the splicing network will be sought by screening for additional enhancers that produce an opened immature flower phenotype in the sr45 mutant background. Mutant phenotypes will be further characterized by scanning electron microscopy, and the splicing patterns of potential gene targets will be analyzed using RT-PCR. Together, these approaches will provide new insights into the role of alternative splicing in plant development.

Broader Impact: Undergraduate students will be engaged in a unique research experience that can be replicated at other undergraduate institutions. First, through a partnership between St. Bonaventure University and the University of Maryland, students will be exposed to active research by gaining first-hand laboratory experience at both institutions and by attending national and international conferences. Second, a new integrative course, Plant Development and Physiology, including research-based lectures, open-ended research lab sessions, and interactive discussions, will be designed and offered to undergraduates at the sophomore/junior/senior level. Prior to each lab session, a student will be designated and trained to lead the lab with help from the instructor. Students from the entire class will participate in generating a poster describing their combined results from all lab sessions and share co-authorship. One student will be selected to present the poster at a conference. This innovative design will engage students in critical thinking, active research and creative discussion. All the opportunities provided to the students in this project are aimed at stimulating enthusiasm and building research experience in preparation for future careers in scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to discover gene networks that an RNA splicing activator, SR45, functions in, and to use this research opportunity as a resource to prepare college students for their future career paths from the classroom.

 

RNA splicing is a process where the genetic messages get edited so it can be used to make proteins. An RNA splicing activator is a protein that promotes this process. We use a plant species, Arabidopsis (a.k.a. mouse-ear cress), for this study. Arabidopsis is recognized as a model organism in the research field because it is a well-established system for scientists to explore a large variety of research questions. 

 

In the cell, proteins work collaboratively and form networks. In an effort to discover the network that SR45 belongs to, we identified seven proteins that associate with SR45. Although these associations are not well understood, we found that SR45 protein function is sensitive to a specific modification by phosphorous. Maybe this modification helps switch the protein on/off or controls other proteins to communicate with SR45. This is extremely interesting because now we are looking at a group of proteins making their own communities to influence the livelihood of a cell.

 

In addition to these seven proteins, we found an enzyme, KIN11, that works with SR45 to promote seed production in plants. KIN11 and SR45 also work together to control how plants respond to glucose. This enzyme exists in human as well, but with a different name, 5’ adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase (AMPK). Scientists have found that some diabetes patients have mutations in AMPK, which makes this enzyme a potential target for cures. Research shows that AMPK regulates many aspects of metabolisms and energy status in a cell. We found a novel mutation in KIN11. By studying how this mutation affects the enzyme activity, our research can contribute to the current understanding in metabolic diseases, such as diabetes.

 

To integrate the above project into the biology curriculum, I designed a new course, Plant Development and Physiology, with a focus on student active learning. In this course, students spend the entire semester to address a research question: how do mutations in SR45 and KIN11 affect the fitness of a plant? They assess a set of genetic mutants for SR45 and KIN11 through the entire plant life cycle and in different environmental conditions, and draw conclusions based on their observations. This course has increased student awareness and appreciation toward plant research and the connection between classroom learning and real world problems. The course design also provides various training opportunities for career competencies, such as introducing own research to general public, preparing and leading a laboratory session, a habit of critical thinking, and writing a research proposal. Students have found it a good preparation for their transition from college to the next step toward their careers in sciences. This course design has been successfully adapted in a different course with a focus in molecular cell biology.
